DOC.HEAD: Police Disarm Another Mail Bomb at Jacksonville, Fla., NAACP Office

Eds: Leads with 29 grafs to UPDATE with Thornburgh comment, further Sessions comment, NAACP offices nationwide told to tighten security, television station receiving letter declaring war on 11th Circuit, DELETES outdated Sessions comment. Picks up 25th graf of a0722: ``He said they ...
LaserPhotos SAV1,2, AX4
DOC.TEXT: Police on Tuesday disarmed a parcel bomb at the NAACP office in Jacksonville, Fla., the fourth in a series of mail bombs that killed an alderman in Savannah, Ga., and a federal judge in Alabama. U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said in Washington that investigators were ``concentrating on a possible racial motivation'' for the rash of mail bombs that began Saturday. FBI Director William Sessions said an organized group might be involved. Savannah officials and the FBI confirmed that the parcel bomb that killed Alderman Robert Robinson on Monday was similar to those that killed 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals Judge Robert S. Vance on Saturday and forced the evacuation Monday of the courthouse in Atlanta that includes the 11th Circuit. An FBI agent said the Alabama and Georga bombs all had different postmarks, phony return addresses and too many postage stamps. Elsewhere Tuesday, an anonymous caller threatened to kill a federal judge in Alabama. A package delivered to a Birmingham, Ala., city councilman who was a friend of Vance was found to be harmless. The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People instructed its 1,800 branch offices and seven regional offices to tighten security because the bombs might be racially motivated, Executive Director Benjamin Hooks said from the organization's headquarters in Baltimore. The discovery of the parcel bomb at the NAACP's Jacksonville office prompted police to evacuate and cordon off the building. The bomb was disarmed inside the building with a device that disconnected the battery from the explosive, officials said. ``It was designed to kill the individual that opened this package or anyone else standing in the area,'' said Jacksonville Sheriff Jim McMillan. ``It had a great similarity in the packaging to the other bombs,'' said Willi Ellison of the U.S. Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. ``It was addressed to no one specifically, but to the legal staff of the NAACP.'' The bomb was to be taken to an FBI laboratory in Washington and compared with the other devices, Ellison said. The package arrived at the NAACP office Monday, but had been left unopened. A series of bomb threats and scares hit federal buildings around Florida, but no other explosive devices were found. Thornburgh said in a statement that he had contacted civil rights leaders ``to assure them that we are fully committed to the vigorous investigations of these crimes and the apprehension of the person or persons'' who committed them. The FBI and Thornburgh warned civil rights leaders, judges and attorneys that the bombings may be racist attacks, but the attorney general stressed there was no firm conclusion on motivation. A pattern of racist attacks ``has to be one of the factors in the back of all our minds,'' Sessions told a Justice Department news conference. He said the incidents have involved ``federal judges who have heard cases involving racial matters,'' the NAACP and a black civil rights activist. Sessions said it was ``quite possible'' more than one person was involved, and that the bombs might be the work of an organized group. He noted that the incidents had occurred in three states in the 11th Circuit. Sessions said no one had claimed responsibility for the bombs. Robinson, a civil rights activist and lawyer, was fatally wounded by a mail bomb in his law office Monday, hours after the courthouse evacuation in Atlanta. Although he was black, a law colleague said there was little reason to figure him as a target of extremist bombers. Funeral services for Vance will be held Wednesday. U.S. Supreme Court Justice Anthony M. Kennedy, who oversees the 11th Circuit, is expected to attend, along with Sessions and the attorney general. FBI agent Tom Moore in Birmingham said there were ``strong similarities'' between the three bombs. FBI Agent Allen Whitaker in Birmingham said the Georgia and Alabama bombs came in similar packages but were mailed from different places. ``There was not a common postmark,'' Whitaker said. ``All had return addresses of different legitimate persons who had no connection with the packages.'' He said the packages bore an excessive number of postage stamps, apparently to protect the senders from ``a face-to-face meeting with postal employees.'' Authorities in Alabama said the bomb that killed Vance sprayed nails and The Atlanta Constitution reported Tuesday that the Atlanta bomb also contained nails. ``We believed nails were part of this bomb also, and that has been confirmed,'' said Savannah Mayor John Rousakis. He said he learned from the FBI that the Savannah bomb bore a Georgia return address, presumed to be fake. WAPT-TV in Jackson, Miss., reported Tuesday that it received an anonymous letter in August declaring war on the 11th Circuit. The letter was postmarked Aug. 21, one day a mail bomb tear-gas attack on the NAACP's Atlanta offices. ``We turned it right over to the FBI,'' reporter Deanna Lee said in a telephone interview. FBI spokesman Charles Steinmetz an investigation into the letter began soon after the television station had passed it along. Joseph Lowery, president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference in Atlanta, said he received a call from Thornburgh expressing concern over the possible racial motive in the bombings.
